utterances: Unidentified Man #2: (Speaking foreign language)
Sitting inside the sweltering hot cafe in Kadhimiyah, Petraeus sips a small cup of tea, a local Iraqi army colonel at his side.
Building up the Iraqi army and police has been a difficult work in progress.
There are widespread issues of corruption and questions about loyalty.
Even here in Kadhimiyah, some members of the Iraqi security forces have links to the Shiite militias.
And elsewhere, U.S.
forces have trained auxiliary police forces often made up of former Sunni militia members who've recently decided to join the U.S.
fight against al-Qaida.
Petraeus says it gets down to fundamentals.
You have to applaud somebody who decides to turn his weapon on al-Qaida instead of on you.
This area grew quite prosperous during the 1980s, but after 9/11, there were many arrests of undocumented people, stores closed, people left the country.
Asghar Choudhri heads the Pakistani American Merchants Association and says people used to come here to buy all kinds of goods.
Then the rumors started: don't go to Brooklyn, don't go to Coney Island Avenue.
The FBI is walking around there.
They were scared.
Now, though, the area is picking up again.
But Choudhri says the response to the devastating floods has been slow.ï¿½
You don't see American media showing too much about the flood.
Just the other day, he says, a Democratic Party organizer called, asking for money for a campaign to keep control of Congress.
She said we want money.
I said do you know what's going on in Pakistan?
I said, you people should feel shame.
You should give us money.
Over there, people are dying.
He also says many people are wary of Pakistan's government.
This sentiment is echoed by Taj Akbar, an accountant who talks to me in the offices of the Khyber Travel Agency.
Akbar comes from Nowshera, one of the most damaged regions.
My family is here, but the relatives over there, yes, there are severely affected by the flood.
And many have been displaced.
When Akbar talks about aid, he says he sees little enthusiasm.
I believe that the people don't trust the government.
He says people are, instead, giving to private organizations they trust.
A few blocks down Coney Island Avenue is one of them, the Council of Peoples Organization.
A handwritten sign in Urdu asking for aid was put on the door right after the floods started.
Inside the door, you immediately see a small collection of donated canned goods.
Mohammad Razvi is the group's executive director.
The organization teaches English and computer classes and gives legal advice.
Razvi shows me flyers and banners that will go to the Ramadan dinners held by each of the five New York City borough presidents.
Ramadan is typically a time of charitable giving.
When asked why it's been slow, he also has several reasons.
I mean, it could be people economically are down at this moment.

But he also says that many didn't realize the scope of the disaster until about a week ago, and he partly blames the Pakistani government for shutting down two widely watched television stations for several days.
They watch those shows, Geo TV and ARY, and they would see more of the hardships that the people are going through.
They weren't able to see that for, you know, for a while.
And now they are seeing it, they're like, oh, my God.
Oh, my God.
Mohsin Zaheer works for Sada e Pakistan, the Voice of Pakistan, one of a half dozen Pakistani community newspapers in New York City.
He tells of one merchant who put up 16 charity boxes in all of his candy stores.
They filled up quickly.
He takes me onto the street and into a grocery store.
The owner is Sajjad Butt.
He sells everything from Cheerios to dates.
Spices, tea.
That's ice cream.
I'll try it, sure.
You will love this.
I will love this?
Now what is this it's called?
Kulfi.
Oh, it's delicious.
He says people here are raising money, including him.
I do myself.
I do every day, like $20, put it in separate for every day.
Money poured into Pakistan after the 2005 earthquake.
Jehangir Khattak covered the community's response to that event.
I don't see any comparison, because people are not responding to the calamity the way that we saw in 2005.
There's a huge trust deficit.
Khattak is the communications manager for New York Community Media Alliance, a group that includes some 350 ethnic and community newspapers in New York City.
He says people are now launching their own efforts.
Giving away money to charities or going themselves into the field and helping those who are in need.
But that is taking time, and in Pakistan right now, time is of the essence.
Margot Adler, NPR News, New York.
(Soundbite of music)
It's MORNING EDITION, from NPR News.
From NPR News, it's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Guy Raz.
New Hampshire voters could make Mitt Romney's nomination a near certainty on Tuesday.
Every presidential candidate in modern history who's won both Iowa and New Hampshire has gone on to win the party's nomination.
And so this morning at the final debate before the vote, five of the six remaining candidates directed most of their fire at, as expected, front-runner Mitt Romney.
Look, can we drop a little bit of the pious baloney?
But I don't see how we can do well against Obama if we have any candidate that, you know, endorsed single-payer systems and TARP bailouts and challenge...
He wouldn't stand up for conservative principles, he ran for Ronald Reagan.
If you can't take the heat, get out of the kitchen.
Sounds from the debate in New Hampshire this morning.
Since 1920, New Hampshire has been the first state to hold a presidential primary, and Granite State voters guard that status fiercely.
Our cover story today: the New Hampshire effect: the birthplace and sometimes graveyard for presidential hopefuls.
In a moment, how Pat Buchanan almost ripped the Republican Party apart in 1996, and later, Gary Hart on his insurgent victory in the state in 1984.
Well, there's no doubt that one of the most significant features of this race has been Romney's failure to expand his own electorate.
In other words, he's pretty much getting the same vote totals that he got last time.
It's just that the field of candidates against him is so fractured, they're dividing the anti-Romney vote.
He hasn't won over social conservatives.
He hasn't won over the most conservative voters in his party.
That may not be an impediment to him getting the nomination, but it is something to watch as he becomes, most likely, a general election candidate.
Mm-hmm.
Prominent evangelicals are in Texas this weekend.
They went there to figure out who they are going to gather around and support.
What do we know about that meeting?

Well, we know that all along, evangelicals and social conservatives and even Tea Party conservatives have not been happy with Mitt Romney, and they are trying to see if at this late hour, they can coalesce behind someone - that might be Rick Santorum - but there are some questions about this.
One, is it too late for anybody to put together the kind of campaign to actually challenge Mitt Romney?
And, two, can these evangelicals and conservatives get behind one candidate?
There's still people who are for Newt Gingrich, some are for Santorum, some are waiting to see if Perry can actually revive himself in South Carolina.
So I think it's a little late for the social conservatives to try this.
Mara, Romney seems to see the light at the end of the tunnel, but there is still damage to be done to him.
I mean, a SuperPAC backing Gingrich is planning a mini-documentary about Romney's time in Bain Capital.
Other candidates are saying he's a crypto-liberal.
There's a subtext to the attacks that he's not a true Christian.
Will these attacks create lasting damage for Romney if he does, indeed, become the nominee?
Well, that's a very good question.
I've been thinking about that a lot.
You know, Mitt Romney is not a beloved candidate.
He doesn't spark a lot of passion among Republicans.
And there is a question as to what would happen to the enthusiasm gap.
Republicans had a lot more enthusiasm than Democrats, but if they nominate someone they're not crazy about, would some of that enthusiasm advantage go away for them?
But I do think that the desire to defeat Barack Obama will be all the unifying force that Romney needs.

And the other thing to remember are the very things that make Romney suspect to conservatives are the same things that make him a stronger general election candidate with the ability to reach out to moderates and independents.
